discussion.author: martinvanleeuwen
discussion.text:
Hi Eric,

I have renamed the package to:

JayTracer

and resubmitted my registration on JuliaHub. I also added [compat] lines to
the Project.toml file. I hope I did that right. I found this explanation:

https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/compatibility/

but that webpage does not explain how to come up with upper bound values.
Do you just have to indicate some future (i.e. not yet existent) version
number? So, if a dependency is at version 0.2.3 I would just use 0.3 as the
upper bound under [compat]?

Thanks,

Martin

discussion.author: ericphanson
discussion.text:
Great! I will close this one then in favor of the new one: https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/32270.

> I also added [compat] lines to
the Project.toml file. I hope I did that right. I found this explanation:
>
> https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/compatibility/
>
> but that webpage does not explain how to come up with upper bound values.
Do you just have to indicate some future (i.e. not yet existent) version
number? So, if a dependency is at version 0.2.3 I would just use 0.3 as the
upper bound under [compat]?

If you just put `name_of_dependency = "0.2.3."`, that actually means "any version [semver](https://semver.org/) compatible with 0.2.3" which means any version on or after 0.2.3 but strictly before 0.3. So the upper bounds are actually implicit already when you use that syntax.
